G.L. c. 223, \u00a72.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §2, because the events giving rise to this claim occurred within Middlesex County, and Defendant transacts business therein.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a74.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 212, §4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000 exclusive of interest and costs.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or occupier owes a duty of reasonable care to maintain the premises in a condition reasonably safe for lawful visitors.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The concurrence excerpt itself focuses on treatment of trespassers, but Mounsey v. Ellard as a whole is the seminal Massachusetts decision abolishing the common‑law distinction between licensees and invitees and imposing a general duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors. The majority holds that occupiers must act as reasonable persons in maintaining premises safe for lawful visitors. Thus, while the quoted passage is not the operative holding, the case overall supports the stated proposition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: [From the majority opinion in Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973)] "We therefore hold that a property owner or occupier owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors."

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries, losses, and damages.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The concurring opinion expressly states that the facts would not warrant a jury finding that the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence. This rejects, rather than supports, a conclusion that the defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. Thus, the case is being used contrary to its actual holding on causation and foreseeability.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73 (1959).proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries, losses, and damages.
Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73 (1959).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that both the trustees (owners) and the elevator company were liable because their negligent inspection/maintenance of the elevator and safety devices resulted in the elevator’s fall and plaintiffs’ injuries. The court explains that the accident would not have happened but for the inoperative interlocks and governor and affirms that the defendants are liable to the injured elevator passengers and operator, thus recognizing a direct causal link between the negligence and plaintiffs’ damages. While the case is not phrased in terms of the formulaic words 'direct and proximate cause,' the causation analysis functionally supports that proposition.
Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73 (1959).relevant_excerpt: There was expert opinion evidence that the accident happened because one of the contact boxes became unfastened and fell into the pit, lodging in the mechanism and severing the cables. Had the interlock system been operating, the cab would have been immobilized when the contact box fell and the accident could not have happened. Nor could it have occurred had the governor been in working order. ... There was ample evidence, which we need not repeat, of [Bay State’s] negligence in inspecting and maintaining the elevator. The plaintiffs ... were unquestionably within the class of persons likely to be injured by its negligence.

Krasnecky v. Meffen, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 4.raw_text: Krasnecky v. Meffen, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 418 (2002)
Krasnecky v. Meffen, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 4.proposition: Defendant’s employees and agents acted within the scope of their employment at all relevant times, imposing vicarious liability on Defendant under the doctrine of respondeat superior, see Krasnecky v. Meffen, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 418 (2002).
Krasnecky v. Meffen, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 4.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with dog-owner statutory strict liability, emotional distress, loss of consortium, and trespass relating to dogs killing plaintiffs’ sheep. It does not address vicarious liability, respondeat superior, or whether any employees or agents were acting within the scope of employment. The proposition about employees/agents and respondeat superior is therefore unrelated to the issues decided in Krasnecky and is not supported by this case.
Krasnecky v. Meffen, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 4.relevant_excerpt: That statute, in pertinent part, makes the owner or keeper of a dog strictly liable for any damage caused by that dog “to either the body or property of any person.” … We conclude that the damages sought by the plaintiffs, in the circumstances, are unavailable to them as matter of law, and that, at most, the only damages to which they are entitled are the nominal damages that they have been awarded.

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: The foreseeability of harm from improperly stacked merchandise is well‑established under Massachusetts premises‑liability principles.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The case does not deal with improperly stacked merchandise; it concerns a grape on the floor in a self‑service grocery store and the adoption of the mode‑of‑operation rule for transitory hazards like spilled produce. While the opinion discusses foreseeability of hazards from a self‑service produce setup, it does not establish any specific, well‑settled Massachusetts principle about harm from improperly stacked merchandise as such. Using this case specifically for that proposition would stretch its holding beyond its facts and reasoning.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “In particular, as is the case here, fruit and vegetable debris presents an obvious risk of injury to a customer, and a reasonably prudent person would not place these items in an aisle or allow them to remain there. Thus, because the determination of reasonableness is a question of fact, the trier of fact must determine whether the owner could reasonably foresee or anticipate that a foreseeable risk stemming from the owner’s mode of operation could occur and whether the owner exercised reasonable care in maintaining the premise in a safe condition commensurate with these foreseeable risks.”

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: A reasonably prudent store operator would have foreseen the likelihood that customers or carts would contact shelving units and cause unsecured boxes to fall.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion deals entirely with premises liability for slip-and-fall injuries on snow and ice in a parking lot and the abolition of the natural/unnatural accumulation rule. It does not involve merchandise shelving, falling boxes, customer contact with store fixtures, or foreseeability of such incidents in a retail context. Nothing in the court’s reasoning addresses how a reasonably prudent store operator should foresee or manage risks related to shelving units or unsecured boxes, so it does not support the stated proposition.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice … the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.proposition: Defendant’s negligence constitutes a failure to exercise ordinary care under the circumstances, Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988); Decker v. Black & Decker Mfg. Co., 389 Mass. 35 (1983).
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly defines negligence as a failure to exercise the degree of care that an ordinarily prudent person would exercise under the circumstances, and then applies that ordinary/ reasonable care standard to the defendant’s conduct. Although the court ultimately finds no negligence on these facts, it clearly affirms that negligence is measured by ordinary care under the particular circumstances, which is the proposition for which it is cited.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.relevant_excerpt: “‘Negligence, without qualification and in its ordinary sense, is the failure of a responsible person, either by omission or by action, to exercise that degree of care, vigilance and forethought which, in the discharge of the duty then resting on him, the person of ordinary caution and prudence ought to exercise under the particular circumstances. It is a want of diligence commensurate with the requirement of the duty at the moment imposed by the law.’ … Ordinarily, where a duty of care is established by law, the standard by which a party’s performance is measured is the conduct expected of an ordinarily prudent person in similar circumstances.”

Decker v. Black & Decker Mfg. Co., 389 M.raw_text: Decker v. Black & Decker Mfg. Co., 389 Mass. 35 (1983)
Decker v. Black & Decker Mfg. Co., 389 M.proposition: Defendant’s negligence constitutes a failure to exercise ordinary care under the circumstances, Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988); Decker v. Black & Decker Mfg. Co., 389 Mass. 35 (1983).
Decker v. Black & Decker Mfg. Co., 389 M.case_name: Decker v. Black & Decker Manufacturing Co.
Decker v. Black & Decker Mfg. Co., 389 M.support_reasoning: The Decker opinion is about indemnity and the effect of the workers’ compensation exclusivity provisions; it does not articulate any general definition of negligence as a failure to exercise ordinary care under the circumstances. The word “negligence” appears only descriptively (e.g., in characterizing potential liability of the defendants), not in a way that defines the standard of care or equates negligence with failure to exercise ordinary care. Thus, Decker does not provide authority for the specific negligence proposition cited.
Decker v. Black & Decker Mfg. Co., 389 M.relevant_excerpt: “Such is not the case here. If either Black & Decker or Pittsfield is liable to the plaintiff, it will be as a result of its negligence or breach of warranty. Such liability will not be derivative or vicarious in nature, nor will it be constructive rather than actual.”

Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.proposition: Massachusetts law permits recovery for all reasonably foreseeable consequences of tortious conduct, Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (1982), including medical bills, lost wages, and general damages for pain and suffering.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion in Payton v. Abbott Labs is about the availability and elements of claims for negligent infliction of emotional distress and prenatal injury; it does not state or discuss a general Massachusetts rule that a tortfeasor is liable for all reasonably foreseeable consequences, nor does it enumerate medical bills, lost wages, or pain and suffering as such. Any references to foreseeability are specific to emotional distress standards, not a broad damages principle. Therefore, the case does not support the proposition as cited.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.relevant_excerpt: "We therefore conclude, on the basis of the preceding analysis, that in order for any of these plaintiffs to recover for negligently inflicted emotional distress, she must allege and prove she suffered physical harm as a result of the conduct which caused the emotional distress. ... Finally, the emotional distress for which compensation is sought must be reasonably foreseeable..." (386 Mass. at 556–557).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a785.proposition: Comparative fault does not bar recovery under G.L. c. 231, §85, as Plaintiff did not act negligently or unreasonably in the store.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a76B.proposition: Interest as provided by G.L. c. 231, §6B.
